entry.title: Cycling out of the north
entry.summary:
Many students spend the few days (weeks) after finishing university drinking heavily and enjoying themselves. I however had my eye on an epic bike ride for a few months and used the downtime as the perfect opportunity to cycle from Hull to Leicester.

The whole trip covered 110 miles of Humberside, Lincolnshire and Leicestershire. Passing over the Humber bridge, through Lincoln and through many many villages on the way. It was quite a nice day, conditions were good and my spirits were high throughout. The day started at 6am and I arrived as planned in time for a friends birthday meal out - perfect.

All in all, a great day out cycling and much better than stumbling home at 4am.

entry.title: Touring the North
entry.summary:
It's been a long time since I last posted, a lot has happened but I've largely been touring The North™ on my bike. As usual there has been plenty of development action, however I'll leave that for future posts.

I've also been to plenty of football matches, at the KC here in Hull, Old Trafford and of course the King Power Stadium back in Leicester. As summer approaches and university life comes to a close for good, I'm looking to continue the adventures accross the country, hopefully with some epic summer bike rides around the south.

entry.title: End Of The Tour
entry.summary:
My tour of ‘The South’ finally came to a close as I left IBM in August. It's was a truly epic 14 months of nonstop friend making, code writing, landlord ranting, and train journeys. I’ve spent a large amount of time in London, seeing the sights, planning world domination and enjoying conference talks.

I’ve also been out travelling as far as Bletchley Park and Watford, learning about Alan Turing and the somewhat less important (and fictional) Harry Potter. I’ve also once again spent a sizable number of summer evenings enjoying the company of my friend Rob in Fareham.

Sunset in Winchester. My tour of 'The South' may be over, but I'll be back soon enough no doubt.

More Photos

entry.title: About 30 Minutes
entry.summary:
In the past three years I've had some 'interesting' living experiences, with everything usually descending into madness. Crazy landlords, insane hazards and genuinely disturbing living conditions have all featured in my stories at the pub.

Back in January I fled my last house, which was a good call. It's added about 30 minutes to my journey to and from work every day, however this is an hour filled with satisfaction.

The photo above says it all, no trouble in sight.

entry.title: Touring The South : Trains, Software Engineering & Friends
entry.summary:
IBM Hursley - Hursley House

I’m in the south, and while not being caught in record heat waves and storms I’ve been engineering software, on trains and hanging out with friends. Sometimes all three at once.

The primary reason I’m in the south however, is that I’m working at IBM on work placement. It’s going really well, lots of challenging and interesting work with plenty of chances to learn and network. It’s great being in a environment densely packed with people who are passionate about software.

Outside of work, I’ve spent an awful lot of time on trains. I’ve been to Fareham, Botley and numerous other places, visiting old and new friends. I seem to find myself eating very civilised meals with friend’s families around the south and visiting an awful lot of pubs.National Rail, despite it’s problems, has facilitated some awesome weekends.

I’ve made a whole load of friends, and am positioned well to see some very good old friends during the holidays. Outings out in the south have been great, new people and new places are always the most exciting part of moving across the country.

Side projects continue, several new popping up and a couple (slowly) closing. The thing I love most about side projects is working along side people who are passionate and smart, it makes the work even more rewarding. The south has provided even more people to collaborate with, which of course is awesome, especially when thinking about future plans.

The tour continues.

entry.title: Rounding Up
entry.summary:
Final 12 hour post exam Sanc trip to mark the end of an era.

The past year has once again been pretty crazy, last year I posted a round up and it seems fitting to do the same this year.

I’ve been up to all sorts and kept myself very busy for most of the year – which is good stuff. Modules this year have been solid, interesting and useful. The year even involved using some non .net based technologies (to my delight).

It was not however without any complaints, generally on the admin side of things with some assessments seemingly designed to frustrate and confuse students. This was however limited to one module and was not representative of the whole course.

Overall, in my opinion the department delivered a good standard of education once again.

Once again I have spent a large chunk of my year working on side projects, with a couple of releases, and some cool games made in 24 hours. At least one more app from the last year should be making itself out to market soon, so watch this space.

The housing situation was pretty bleak this year. I intend to do everything in my power to never deal with a student housing company in Hull again. Despite this, housing this year still managed to provide some good times. Trips to Wetherspoons, Model World, Vue and assorted shopping centres all featuring in my highlights. Having a few drinks with some new found history loving acquaintances also proved to be great – a real break from the drama of student life.

I was definitely ready to go home though. On the way to my exam I dropped my keys off and upon finishing I picked up my bags and ran for the bus. See you next time Hull.

Northern Rail's 11:27 Rescue Service

Some highlights:

Getting out and about

Another year of pool

Pub trips

Hanging out with Joe from back home

Being walking distance to University (I do miss the Lawns Bus though)

Many trips to the Union shop and Sanctuary

Awesome group project

Brynmor Jones Library – providing a sanctuary from a terrible student house

Watching WrestleMania with Waseem

Eating far to much takeaway far to often from Prima

Collaborating with my fellow students for side projects – especially Marcin

And ofcourse a lot more

Most of all I enjoyed spending time with the good friends I have acquired in the past two years. Unfortunately the end of this year marks the end of seeing almost all of them during the remainder of my time at University.

Not to worry though, I have a rail card and I’m not afraid to use it.

Home in time for drinks and bowling (something that's rapidly becoming a trend)

Summer lasted just 2 weeks, but I managed to cram a lot of good times in before heading to Winchester.

entry.title: Capturing Attention With Magic
entry.summary:
Magic Development?

Creating great software is key to making what Reto Meier at Google calls “magical apps”. Apps that capture the user’s attention with unprecedented and seemingly ‘magic’ experiences, often leaving the user wondering how it all works.

Zombie Booth is what I would call ‘magic’. It showcases what smartphones can do by combining facial recognition and advanced graphics to create an experience that just a few years ago would have seemed absurd.

Showing the app to friends recently I came to a conclusion that I thought of note. What struck me as interesting is that it didn’t capture our attention for long. In fact it’s quite remarkable display didn’t even warrant a download for the rest of the group. Most of our smartphone time was spent on other, not necessarily ‘magic’, apps.

Zombie Booth has millions of downloads,and it would be farcical to deny it’s success. To me the anecdote has shown that whilst making ‘magical’ experiences is a great way to go, it’s not always enough, at least on its own, to win everyone over.

entry.title: Technology in the Wild : Mobile
entry.summary:
Pringle calling

I like to think of myself as primarily a technology enthusiast. Whilst software engineering is a realistic definition of what I get up to in my academic and ‘real’ life, it doesn’t quite encompass the fascination and appreciation that can be had for technology.

The physical, theoretical and mathematical grounding of technology is fantastic but commanding my attention recently has the been the ‘softer’ side of technology. With the media and Silicon Valley declaring that mobile devices are pivotal to the future of technology and with their ubiquitous presence everywhere we go, it’s never been easier to observe world changing technology in the wild.

The mobile industry is massive, affecting almost everyone on the planet. In just six years since the iPhone was launched, the smartphone revolution has permanently changed the way we think about and use technology. It’s even managed to capture revolutions along the way.

Not long after I saw this display in person, it was torn down as part of the Tunisian revolution, smartphones played a large role in the coverage of the Arab Spring.

In India and across Africa for the first time migrant workers are able to call back home at a low cost thanks to cheap phones and budget telecom providers. Not just familiar voices can be sent back home though, mobile banking allows money to be sent long distance between two mobile numbers using services such as M-Pesa.

Mobile is truly having a huge influence and changing lives in some of the world’s fastest changing places.

It’s not just in far flung places we can see the impact of mobile technology. In the past week alone I was sold a milkshake using an iPad, signed for an Amazon package on an Android device and received photos from Turkey directly from my Dad’s camera.

My Dad yesterday - away from the protests

In an ever more connected world where every day someone has a new app to show off down at the pub, it’s easy to marvel at the wonders surrounding us. But with mobile technology reaching as far as war-zones and space, now is the perfect time to get the smartphone out and think of something new.

And while we’re at it, why not try and change the world in the process.

entry.title: On Broken Windows
entry.summary:
A broken wall at Brynmor Jones Library , is it worth fixing?

When it comes to violent crime and disorder, can one offence lead to another?

According to the Broken Window Theory, yes. It suggests that one act of vandalism left untouched, such as a broken window, creates a sense that the area has been abandoned. This then invites further crimes and eventually what was a minor issue spirals into something more serious altogether.

Whilst the theory is useful reading for those presiding over law enforcement, it also has a place in software engineering. Think about a project of yours, does it have any broken windows? Perhaps undocumented code, dodgy library dependencies or a  ’temporary’ solution that’s been marked “//TODO: fix this” for the past two months.

Fixing such problems promptly can prevent larger issues further down the road. Keeping a project in good shape will keep morale up, promote good software engineering practices and ensure that the project is still cared for.

Of course no project is developed in a perfect world. With restrictions on time, money and resources I think the real skill is to judge what windows can be left and what windows must be fixed. What is for sure though is that keeping track of your windows isn’t a bad idea at all.

Further reading:

Broken Windows – George L. Kelling and James Q. Wilson – The Atlantic

The Pragmatic Bookshelf | Software Entropy

The Pragmatic Programmer – Andrew Hunt, David Thomas ISBN: 978-0201616224

entry.title: About 12 hours
entry.summary:
A good setup

It’s amazing what you can do in about 12 hours. The other day my good friend Tom and I decided to have a “App Jam”. In the space of half a day we managed to come up with a concept from nowhere and ended up with something close to a proof of concept.

That is before we crashed out, If only we hadn’t been suffering from lack of sleep at the start. If we have a 24 hour session during the week, I’m certain we can get our app very workable using maps, gps and bar codes, all good stuff.

I think the best way to go about limited time dev sessions is to get a solid idea, stick with it and make decisions that will ensure you see progress as fast as possible.

As soon as you start to see your physics engine working, or your maps API working, it’s a mental downhill journey from there.

entry.title: Sun, Servers & Suspicious Deals
entry.summary:
One of the nicest views on campus

The Sun’s been out the past week or so. Hull is a much nicer place in the Sun and the Uni looks even better.

We’re now over half way through our degrees, which is absolutely mad. Things that happened over a year ago feel like recent memories. With time flying by so fast it’s important to keep track of what’s gone on. The blog is perfect for this.

The only issue has been my hosting, all sorts of goodies and “99.9%” uptime for no charge. It seemed too good to be true and for the most part was.

I’ve been meaning to switch to a proper hosting plan for months, and managed it smoothly thanks to some quick research and some SQL skills. I’ve now got much more flexibility with the site and as a result can rest easy at night knowing everything’s safe and in good working order.

entry.title: Iterating Towards Insanity : Game Jam
entry.summary:
A couple of weeks ago was Global Game Jam, a 48 hour game dev event, this year’s theme was the sound of a heart beating. Our local event was hosted at Hull College with students present from Hull, Grimsby and around Yorkshire. I thoroughly enjoyed the weekend and most of all bonding with my fellow course mates.

I teamed up with Marcin who arrived half way through. I spent the first day messing around with our Android engine of choice : AndEngine. A nice engine, but the documentation did not lend itself to my perhaps insane stance of “lets use something that’s not XNA and it doesn’t matter if we’ve never used it before”.

Marcin arrived on Saturday, 24 hours in and with no sleep we began making a game.

Work underway

We were seated next to the “Heart Attack Team”, consisting of John, Nick and Tom. These guys helped make the weekend, sharing trips to the shops and just chatting helps keep you sane. I also enjoyed some quality “banter” with Beta Jester and Mateusz, all great guys who seemed to get a lot more sleep than myself.

We ended up at Wetherspoons for breakfast, where I was pretty much delirious with lack of sleep, I still managed a 1400 calorie meal though.

As the event progressed and as the time between commits became longer and the bugs became more ridiculous, me and John came up with the very appropriate phrase “iterating towards insanity”.

John - well on his way to insanity Overall I really enjoyed Game Jam, although I would have preferred if there was no competition aspect. It’s better just “jamming” the way musicians do and having a good time sharing our common interests.

Not forgetting the game, Doodle Heart, which is available now for Android. It’s doodle themed, high score based,physics fun. We love it.

Many thanks to the guys at Hull College, Simon Grey and everyone who ran the event, and of course to Marcin who is a pleasure to work with  - more from us in the pipeline.

Thoughts from Game Jam:

Git really is better than SVN, especially with a dodgy network / Hull Uni SVN.

Drinking loads of Robinsons and having 0 caffeine keeps you awake for days.

Simple ideas are the king of game dev events.

Polish goes a long way.

XNA is infact optional.

As always, a good tunes lifts morale #isWasntMe

entry.title: 3TG : No Method, No Class & Monkeys
entry.summary:
![Imported Image]alt

Game mechanics involving angry, vicious and thirsty monkeys.

In October I teamed up with Shaun and John (both first years) for Three Thing Game, a 24 hour game dev event here at the University of Hull.

Monkeys, power ups, caffeine and insane "caffeine high" techno mode gameplay

To summarise, I drank obscene amounts of Robinsons whilst we made a brilliant game that made players smile.

We made the finals and presented something we, and everyone else loved.

No Method(), No Class{} having a rest

The only criticism I have for Three Thing Game this time around was the judging/judging criteria.

How well it matched the three things

Completeness

Fun to play

We hit all three well and were disappointed to see what we thought was judging not based on the criteria. Great graphics and complex game play are impressive, but surely having a solid story line and fun complete game play take precedence.

Despite this a great time was had making a great game. Which to me is far more important than winning Microsoft swag.

Game over, time for bed.

Many congratulations to all those involved, lots of great competition.

entry.title: Hullfire Android
entry.summary:
Looks good!

After my exams finished I decided to go ahead and blast out an app for The Hullfire. Myself  Sam Cooke and Mark Dyer had been in discussion about Hullfire apps and also developing a web framework for the content during the past semester.

Tablet support also

The only thing left to do was to finish building it.


Good stuff I think.

entry.title: Busy
entry.summary:
The local has jelly beans now #result

It’s been an incredibly busy past couple of months. Most notably I’ve been down to Winchester for an IBM assessment centre which was a great experience, it felt like the young apprentice, but with nice people.

A Christmas tree in Winchester. May I one day be blessed with a steady hand when I'm on the go

Working on my own projects, hunting for a placement and getting all the coursework done has been hard work, but It’s a good feeling when you start to see it all pay off.

I’ve been up to all sorts this semester, none of which I had really expected, so who knows what the new year will bring.

There's not enough Indian takeaways in Hull. Leicester's Bombay Bites makes up for the absence though

Being home for Christmas has been great, home is pure luxury compared to student living. I’ve been working hard on some apps but have managed to relax a little after the semester with countless trips to the pub and takeaways. It’s always great to catch up with the mates.

entry.title: Demo 2012
entry.summary:
On the road once again.

On November 21st, thousands of students took to the streets of London to shout at the government in protest of rising tuition fees and education cuts.

Signs everywhere. Socialists tried to convert us too.

It was another epic adventure with Joe and an experience you can only get as a student.

A testament to my photography skills #curseTheTrees

The only problem was the highly persistent rain which was more powerful than my shower.

On the beat and gave us many a wave.

No ifs, no buts, no education cuts!

entry.title: November 5th & 11th
entry.summary:
We went over to Tom and Joe’s house for fireworks. Cracking night of fireworks and a roaring fire, a great trial for my new coat. The only down side being that I didn’t take any pictures.

It’s Diwali time in Leicester, the lights are up all over the place. Gotta love the golden mile, you just don’t experience other cultures like this in Hull.

Paramedic dodging blurry photo taking skills #trainLeftBeforeSwitchOn

On Sunday myself, Josh, Joe and Oli smarted up and walked into Hull for the Annual Remembrance Service at the Cenotaph. It was nice to pay some respects, and sacrificing a student lie in is nothing compared to the sacrifices of those who have served for us.

After this we stumbled into a Hull wartime exhibition. We spent a good hour chatting to the guys running the place and got keyed up on our local wartime knowledge.

Josh manning a rather large machine gun

We made our way to a greasy spoon for breakfast and rather humorously ended up looking like a losing team from the apprentice (only with more brains). The food was ok, but I didn’t get the hash browns I ordered, well you can’t have it all I guess.

entry.title: Out with Labour
entry.summary:
The other day I headed out with my good friend Joe and the University’s Labour Club to campaign on behalf of John Prescott. He’s running for Humberside Police and Crime Commissioner.

The People's Voice

I think he’s a good candidate for the job and I got a great experience out in Bransholme North leafleting with the Labour folks. Something much different from the average Comp Sci day.

It's not every day Prescott serves you curry #badPhotographySkills

Make sure you vote on November 15th, no matter what your political alignment is!

entry.title: Caffeine, Monkey, Under Attack – No Method(), No Class{}
entry.summary:
Bransholme, North Hull at night. #irrelevant

Three Thing Game is back on. This time I’m on-board with an entirely new team consisting of me, Shaun and John. Awesome team name too, well played Shaun.

We’ve got Caffeine, Monkey and “Under Attack”. A good combination if you ask me, here’s hoping nothing goes horrifically wrong (ha).

I didn’t even get Visual Studio 2010 installed and running until the early hours of Thursday.

No matter though, the intense coding sessions have begun, looking forward to Saturday.

Game on.

entry.title: Call Me, Love Me
entry.summary:
The stage

The Samaritans have been in Hull for 50 years. As a celebration the drama department presented a three night showing of “Call Me, Love Me”. In part directed by my housemate Julian and written by Melanie Ball, it followed the story of a number of linked characters going through tough situations in their lives. Call Me, Love Me really showcased some great Hull talent and proved to be a good night’s entertainment. Increased awareness forthe Samaritans is top stuff too.

As a Software Development student, living with drama students certainty adds some variety to Uni life.

Find out more:

http://www.samaritans.org/

http://www.samaritans.org/how-we-can-help-you/contact-us

entry.title: Hull Fair
entry.summary:
An awesome piece of engineering

The Hull Fair was back in town, good stuff. We went on this crazy ride pictured above. It was great for the first three minutes, then the last two reminded me of years of trips to Scotland.

All in all a good time, didn’t get on the dodgems though, maybe next time.

entry.title: Windows 8 Convert
entry.summary:
I’ve been hating the release preview for Windows 8 on my laptop for ages. It’s trying far too hard to be a tablet. It’s just like being on a mobile device with all the UI design choices and sacrifices that come with the territory.

Irrelevant steak, it was awesome though #greyMare

But then I treated myself with a nice SanDisk SSD for my desktop and took the plunge and installed Windows 8 from DreamSpark. It’s pretty awesome. I have a few gripes, but the machine is running fast and there’s a lot of good stuff I’m loving in Windows 8. I’m still not absolutely 100% on metro but it’s not a problem.

It’s great to be up to date with a proper build of 8, the experience on my PC is so much better than on the laptop. I’m hoping a clean reformat and install will bring the laptop experience up to scratch. Fingers crossed.

entry.title: Calling Three Thing Gamers
entry.summary:
Milk Shack - Newland Avenue #treatYourself

So Three Thing Game is back on.

I need a team, or if a team needs +1, I’m in.

contact@alexpringle.co.uk

entry.title: Freshers
entry.summary:
Tinchy Stryder

Freshers week was once again a blur, good stuff though. Perhaps the best part of freshers is that people actually talk, they haven’t got locked into a small group of friends yet. Random encounters are the order of the day, excellent.

A big highlight for me was helping freshers move in at The Lawns. It was a great feeling helping people out, chatting to parents and giving them a good first impression.Living in halls was a fantastic experience and seeing all the freshers was exciting.

Being at Uni is crazy, one minute you’re watching Tinchy Stryder get “grimey” with his lyrics, next your sinking into an arm chair listening to an in depth conversation about 30′s media and racial stereotypes. Quality.

entry.title: Home Sweet Hull
entry.summary:
So summer ended how it started, with a trip to the pub. I’m back in Hull and in-between putting my foot down at our housing provider’s office I’ve been at the pub, playing minecraft with H-bomb & Dean and turning my Raspberry Pi into a media center for the living room.

On the road once again

The Humber Bridge in the sun.

Got the case today, it looks epic. Great piece of hardware

Went to Uni for a gander - Robert Blackburn at night

Year 2 approaches

entry.title: A Pleasant PC World Experience
entry.summary:
My 5.1 speakers decided to die the other day, after threatening to for months. I started googlingfor something more practical for Uni and I ended upchoosingthe Creative Gigaworks T40.

Looking and sounding good

They look and sound great and I can’t wait to set them up in Hull and get some tunes on. I was pleasantly surprised when I found out they were available at a mere £3 more than Amazon at PC World, shocking considering PC World’s prices. I headed into Leicester to get some and I even got to try some out in the shop. Normally I hate PC World, but they’ve impressed on this occasion.

entry.title: Football
entry.summary:
4-1 victory over Hinckley United (who?)

I’m not really a football fan but this summer I’ve been to a couple of LCFC pre season friendlies. I’m not saying I’m lucky but 2/2 wins so far, maybe I should go to some games during the season.

1-0 victory against Sunderland

entry.title: New devices & new features
entry.summary:
Quality tablet

So I’ve acquired a Nexus 7, it’s the latest Nexus branded device and the first tablet from Google. It’s awesome, and priced amazingly cheap. It’s the third Nexus device with a NFC chip, which allows for short distance communication between two devices by bringing the backs together.

Amy's new Galaxy S3

With the NFC enabled Samsung Galaxy S3 taking a massive share of the smartphone market I figured it would be a good idea to play around with some NFC features. I’ve just added sharing support to Hull CS Blogs using Android Beam, and it works very well.

entry.title: Hull CS Blogs Android & Greece
entry.summary:

It’s pretty close to being finished (and would be if I wasn’t hiding in the shade halfway across the world #ginger)

entry.title: Paradise City
entry.summary:
So we all went to Skegness the other day for what I insisted was a holiday (despite everyone saying it was a day trip).

We all arrived at half 8, all set for an epic road trip.

Assembled at 8:30am

First stop, Mc D’s for breakfast. Barnes and Sam ended up somewhere else but caught up on the route later (to mine and Adam’s delight).

Breakfast stop

After this is was full speed to Skegness. We we’re singing Paradise City at the top of our voices and enjoying some dubstep when the sun made an appearance.

A promising sight

First things first we hit the beach.

It's a beach with a pier

Then we strolled on down to the arcades where Massey “won big”.

Such a high roller

After this followed some bowling, some shopping and many unsuccessful attempts by me to win cuddly toys.

A clock

Wild times on the attractions

As the day came to a close, it was on to the “dubious” Beijing Dragon.

A dubious but reasonable place to dine

We managed to acquire a number of goldfish on our travels, which we’re named  Enrique, Fred (or gold-finger) and something else I can’t remember.

Adam called him Gold-finger, but apparently he's called Fred.

Unfortunately the day had to come to an end, it was a great time and everyone seemed to enjoy themselves thoroughly.

Messing around before heading home

Good times, great friends, bring on the next road trip.

entry.title: Nclip, Android fragmentation and a fancy image
entry.summary:
Recently I’ve been working on updating Nclip, which hasn’t seen much in the way of love from me for many months. I’ve spent a few hours adding some highly requested features and also getting it to look like a proper ICS app. My main problem now is getting it to look respectable on older versions of Android (which make the majority of my user base).

I’m using a library called ActionBarSherlock, which has eased some pain, but there’s still an inevitable hit to productivity ensuring everything looks good on every supported version of the OS.

Fancy graphic using - Android Asset Studio

Android Asset Studio : http://android-ui-utils.googlecode.com/hg/asset-studio/dist/index.html

entry.title: End Of Year Ball
entry.summary:
It was the End Of Year Ball at Uni a couple of weeks ago, we all looked pretty swish and had a good night of drinks, music and laughs. It was good seeing 9 months of new friends and acquaintances all looking sharp, a top notch way to end the year. Good stuff.

Looking good I say

Downs C Comp Sci

The Main Stage

entry.summary:

Fountain @ Leicester Town Hall Square

So Dropbox is awesome, if I need anything,anytime its on my phones, pc, laptop, the web and the tablet. I started using it ten times more since I got to uni so get it, it’s pretty badass.

entry.title: Hot hot hot

entry.title: Year 1 at Hull Uni
entry.summary:
So the end of my first year at Hull Uni is fast approaching, it’s been pretty insane. There are only a couple of exams left and I probably should be revising for them.

There was a nice rainbow the other day

All considered it’s been a good year and I’ve seen good results so far, with regards to work I have mainly been focusing on my own projects and goals. I’ve managed to build up some example software and gain loads of knowledge in my free time whilst having a great time as a fresher. One of the biggest problems I’ve found this year is keeping my focus on one thing, there’s so many half finished things I have on the go and I still keep starting new projects – no worries though, it’s all good fun.

Stopped a Sheffield one time #randomPictures

A few things I have hated this year:

The Lawns being so far away from the University

Some 105 bus drivers

Students outright insulting Mike Brayshaw (he has passion, so what if it’s for Unix and trains)

The guy who harasses people in labs and attempts to bribe students/demonstrators into doing his coursework.

Having to tell people to be quiet in tutorials

Most of the Lawns food (although it is cheap)

Being abandoned at Three Thing Game

Apparent variance in marking styles of programming coursework between markers

At the bus stop at 7am #randomPictures

A few highlights:

New friends, girlfriend, flatmates and acquaintances

The insane blur that was freshers

Three Thing Game

Guest lectures + talks

Free Blackberry Playbook

Reasonable app success

Cheap bars

Heron Foods

Enter Shikari

Bang Tidy Fridays at Sanctuary

Bing Wang Breakfasts (fry up after his 9am lecture)

No pointless A-levels

Not being treated like dirt by staff (like at college)

Getting good quality teaching and feedback

Lectures and staff that are happy to talk to you (and not down), email back promptly and go out of their way to assist you (even in their free time)

Great resources and environment for getting work done (especially the intranet, library & labs)

A department that goes out of their way to notify you of any events,competitions or opportunities to aid your education (and stuff that’s just fun)

and of course, the union shop

Summer approaches.

entry.title: Enter Shikari
entry.summary:
So months ago I saw that Enter Shikari were going to come to Hull University and play at Asylum. I had promised myself that I would go see them should they come to Hull, so that was that,I booked my ticket and more or less forgot about it.

Sorting the hair at TLC

A few months passed an eventually March came round, nobody else I knew had bothered to get tickets, which didn’t bother me, it was going to be epic anyway.

Young Guns on stage

As it turns out Amy managed to get hold of a ticket and the whole thing turned into an epic date.

Epic white light

We started off at TLC (The Lawns Bar) where Amy convinced Mike to open up so I could get some JD and Coke.

More lights

Got the bus to Uni, got a couple drinks in Asylum, got a good spot with an ace view and enjoyed Young Guns and Enter Shikari.

Enter Shikari on stage

It was a truly epic night, they played a good mix of old and new in my opinion and most importantly, there was cheesy chips on the way home.

Amazing time.

entry.title: The Unholy Alliance (and why we bailed)
entry.summary:
So Three Thing Game happened the other week, we had dog, flamethrower and party as our things – an improvement on last time: summoner, bomb and speedboat. We rocked up to the 24 hour session with a basic framework for some minigames and some art work.

A healthy healthy breakfast

We also found our name had changed to The Unholy Alliance, maybe next time we’ll go for The Unnamed Alliance or perhaps The Unpredictable Alliance.

We started on some games, I ended up creating a robot wars style battle arena type thing, Waseem ended up working on a maze game, Scott started on “falling kennels” and Danny was working on a dog racing game.

Everyone coding away

Everything was going well, especially considering we came into the session with a casual outlook and next to nothing code wise. Amy turned up late into the evening with biscuits and Pepsi (amazing girlfriend move) and hung out with us creating some graphics. At quarter past ten we all headed off to Mc D’s apart from Danny who decided to stay. Me and Waseem were both keen to keep the Three Thing Game late night Maccys tradition going (we got table service last time).

A dog with a flamethrower and a party hat -Thanks to Dan H for helping with the artwork

After a sizeable meal and discussing how we thought the project would come together nicely we returned at about half 11 to crack on with the coding. When we got back to the lab we found Danny wasn’t at his desk, we thought nothing of it until we checked Facebook.

Apparently Danny didn’t think the project was going anywhere and had decided to go home as he wasn’t enjoing himself, unfortunately  for us he hadn’t left us any of his code or given us a chance to talk him round. This was a big knock to team morale and after a couple of hours of the four of us working (even Amy hadn’t left) we decided to put going home on the result of a triple coin toss. The result – get a cab home.

It's a party hat

It was pretty disappointing seeing as we could see it coming together after starting with nothing on the day. It wasn’t all bad though we enjoyed ourselves for the most part and I got some much needed sleep for Enter Shikari the next day, which as it turns out was a great call.

The important lesson we’ve learned here is to pick your team mates carefully, we’ll certainly be doing Three Thing Game next semester. Bring it on.

entry.title: The BlackBerry PlayBook Saga
entry.summary:
So it all started at the beginning of February when I received an email from the old man who’d been browsing Engadget on his Asus Transformer. Turns out BlackBerry were releasing a update to their tablet (the PlayBook) which included the BlackBerry Android runtime environment and were offering a free PlayBook to anyone who ports their Android app to the platform (new life goal acquired). This lead to me hit the white boards drawing up a 8 day plan to port [Nclip][] to the PlayBook .

The device itself (complete with blog)

After sending of a copy of my ID to BlackBerry I downloaded and fired up the PlayBook simulator and Eclipse plugin. Once everything was up and running I started to remove any features that weren’t compatible with the PlayBook, sadly quite a number of them, pretty lame considering its a simple app and the Android api’s I used were actually highlighted by BlackBerry as being compatible. This wasn’t the only problem, the simulator was slow and confusing and didn’t seem to handle changing orientation correctly.

Nclip running in portrait

Despite this I managed to use my Android knowledge to create a tablet sized UI which looked good. The next step was signing and packaging the app for the BlackBerry App World, the Eclipse plug-in seemed to to a good job and I sent the release to BlackBerry for approval. 6 days later I received notice that my app release had been denied because the file had not been signed properly - strange considering I used all the proper tools. It turned out that the file hadn’t been signed at all, so after much fiddling around with the SDK I managed to get something that looked like it was signed.

But this isn’t the end of the story, the file wouldn’t upload, the signature on the new release didn’t match that of the old release – of course not, it isn’t signed! This led to some slow paced back and forth with developer support, having eventually sorted the problem I sat back and waited for approval.

Two and a half weeks later, I got an email saying the release was approved – success. I only had to provide my shipping details and wait. A further 16 days later, having received a tracking number for someone else’s PlayBook (headed to Budapest) I found my PlayBook waiting for me at The Lawns. Life goal complete.

The screen is superb

The actual tablet is great, and it was well worth the hassle in exchange, plus now I’ve expanded to another platform. I’m intending to do some native development for the tablet soon, which should prove to be more successful with what looks to be a much nicer SDK.

entry.title: Excessive blog choices
entry.summary: So many things to blog about, I haven’t been able to choose. So as a placeholder whilst I decide where to start on my backlog, here’s Downs Hall in the sun.

entry.title: The Unlikely Alliance Roll Again
entry.summary:
A cool team name right, we thought we might as well use it again for this semester’s Three Thing Game. For those not in the know, you acquire 3 “things” , this time via auction (complete with “thing money”), to base your game around. There’s then a week long development period climaxing in a 24 dev session in the labs followed by judging.

This time Danny Q has joined us and we’re current throwing game concepts around, although I feel the urge to have spinning cakes and exploding presents.

More later in the week, back to coding.

www.threethinggame.com

entry.title: Distractions, Android, Linux & Ubuntu
entry.summary:
So Visual Studio blew up the other day taking most of my Windows 7 with it, instead of re-installing or using the laptop I got distracted by loads of other things, including Ubuntu on the Nexus.

Inside the Ubuntu terminal on Android

It's running along side Ice Cream Sandwich

It’s possible because Android runs on top of the Linux kernel. This means any Android device can run an Linux image along side the system so long as it has loop device support built into it’s kernel. No problem for me as I’m using CyanogenMod 9 on the Nexus.

It’s not just a Linux terminal, the image has GNOME and LXDE, both accessible through VNC.

A screenshot from the Nexus

The rest of my devices got in on the action via VNC.

It looks good on the cheap Android tablet. Running Open Office too.

It’s not just a pretty face, why not compile and run some c?.

Nano running smoothly

The program running, success!

So the Nexus runs Ubuntu well on the side, another reason why I love Android so much. It’s also a great example of Linux doing it’s thing.

entry.title: Pub?
entry.summary:
I’m a student and therefore spend a decent amount of time at the pub. Over christmas we ended up talking about apps, In the end we decided it needs to be easier to orginise a trip to the local.

The interface itself

Enter “Pub?” – the app I created in a week, each time adding features after coming back from the local. A true student app.

Instantly let your friends know when and where you want to meet up for drinks with custom text messages.

Features:

Easily store and manage friends/pubs.

Add a time to messages.

Makes your evening better!

entry.title: Nokia Lumia 800
entry.summary:
So my contract ran out, and because I bought my fancy Nexus S with my own cash it means there was no greater phone available to “upgrade” to.

Lock screen looking good

This meant I could grab a Nokia Lumia 800 for no extra charge a month and add another platform to my life. I’m a massive Android fan so it’s been an interesting week so far road testing the competition. It’s a great actual phone, the implementation for calls,texts,emails,music and the calendar has all been fantastic so far. What lets it down for me is Internet Explorer, 6 tabs and no text reflow really leave me wanting to grab the Nexus where I can get a superb experience with Chrome for Android. Another major annoyance for me is the app Marketplace, everything’s hard to find and there doesn’t seem to be much to find in the first place. There’s plenty more things I don’t like, what gets me is that in Android if there’s a problem or something I want to do on the phone I can usually find the answer or do it myself. So far I find this not to be the case on WP7.

A flashy box for a flashy phone

Android gets a lot of stick for things it doesn’t deserve in my opinion. It’s open to modification in any way, sometimes this ends in Orange butchering a phone with their software, but for me it means getting a new super fast build of android with loads of mods, tweaks and features for free every few days. So I can see why people might have issues with their Android phones, unfortunately most of these tend to be completely avoidable had the manufacturers and networks fixed the device up properly. There’s normally solutions available online in places such as XDA-Developers but it’s not viable for everyone to be flashing their phone.

Windows Phone 7 leaves me wanting more in this department but the closed system gives a really good rounded experience – sadly not the default in a lot of android phones. I still have the Nexus and plenty of computing power to build Android, so I’m not missing my Android fix anytime soon. I could go on to talk all day about the two platforms but this blog would be ridiculous.

The hardware design is ace

I’m actually enjoying using the WP7 for day to day life and I guess that’s the important thing when I’m on the move round campus. Also, the Nokia is a brilliant device, the hardware is top notch and it looks superb.

entry.title: Lan
entry.summary:
A panoramic shot, taken with my Nexus S, a feature new to Ice Cream Sandwich

We decided to LAN it up at Tom’s after new year. 8p donuts, a massive pork pie and a load more of co-op finest reduced goods later we were ready to go. The Ship proved to be  a favorite of the night, simply because nothing is quite as satisfying as smashing your mate over the head with a frying pan on a 1920′s cruise liner (and then turning around to gloat).

As usual with Lans, most of our time was spent fixing problems and staring at 9 hour progress bars for left 4 dead 2, still a good time was had by all.

entry.title: Harvester
entry.summary:
Does this need a description? #delicious

Everyone loves pizza hut, but imagine if it was steak instead of pizza. This is what i was pleasantly suprised to find on Sunday at my Nan’s local Harvester in Luton. Pepsi by the bucket load, great helpings of salad bar and a beastly cut of gammon – all the ingredients for a top notch meal with the family. Also featuring a quality chocolate cake to finish things off, all in all another great food experience.

entry.title: Facebook vs SQL
entry.summary: It’s amazing what you can do when you spend some time focusing on something thats not pointless. I just looked up SQL for a while and gained some valuable knowledge, in that time most of my peers have been discussing Jaffa Cakes on Facebook. SQL is genuinely more interesting, how can Facebook be that addictive when there’s an abundance of things to read/learn/do on the internet.

Ryan, pondering epic breakfast tuesdays.
